I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Coal accounts for 29% of global primary energy use and it contributes to almost half of all 
global carbon dioxide emissions.1 The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimates 
that, to keep global temperature increase to below 1.5°C, coal-fired power generation would need 
to decrease by 80% within this decade and be fully decommissioned by 2050. However, coal 
remains a major fuel source responsible for almost 38% of electricity generation worldwide in 
2018 and for a staggering 59% in Asia. Further, as of 2019, Asia accounts for 78% of all planned 
and under-construction  coal  power  plants.2 While  solar photovoltaic  and  wind power  have 
become cost competitive in recent years, direct and indirect subsidies artificially reduce the cost 
of using coal for utilities. The International Monetary Fund recently estimated that subsidies and 
environmental and health-related externalities of fossil fuel generation is equivalent to 6.5% of the 
global gross domestic product.3 
 
2.  Nonetheless, some recent, encouraging changes suggest a possible change in the current 
global energy trend. Firstly, several international institutional investors and banks are starting to 
incorporate environmental, social and governance indicators into their business strategies, which 
support divesting from coal assets and banning financing of coal operations. Secondly, stranding 
risks  are  becoming a  reality  in  various electricity  markets,  as  the  introduction  of  low-cost 
renewable energy capacity is displacing fossil-fueled power plants that often have higher marginal 
costs. It is estimated that 39% of the world’s existing coal power plants currently costs more to 
continue operating than installing and operating new onshore wind or solar photovoltaic with 
storage (with 4-hour storage rated at half the renewable generation capacity), a share that is 
expected  to  increase to  as high as 73% by 2025.4 Over  100  globally  significant  financial 
institutions are already acknowledging asset stranding risks, and have started exiting coal-related 
investments and operations5 (including some of the world’s largest banks, insurance companies, 
and Blackrock, the world’s largest asset manager)6 as greener policies, the lower levelized cost 
of renewable generation plus electricity storage, and the introduction of carbon pricing in energy 
markets increase the likelihood of coal-fired assets becoming stranded well before their technical 
lifetime ends. Similarly, under the Science-Based Targets initiative, 885 companies to date (which 
are large consumers of electricity in many developing member countries [DMCs]) have set climate 
action targets well-below the 2°C or 1.5°C trajectory.7 
 
3.  A key barrier to accelerating the retirement of coal power generation is that most coal 
power plants are insulated from competition by long-term power purchase agreements and 
noncompetitive tariffs. There are limited options to alter these arrangements without facing 
penalties and costs or protracted legal and political battles. Therefore, a phaseout approach to 
dealing with such legacy contractual arrangements and tariff structures would be to incentivize 
coal power plant investors and owners to replace returns from the coal power plants with returns

from  clean  energy  plants  by  reinvesting  the  capital  in  clean  energy.  Governments  and 
international financing institutions, like the Asian Development Bank (ADB), could support this 
effort by financing the coal transition, saving money to customers and taxpayers, and reducing 
local air pollution and carbon emissions. 
 
4.  While the early retirement of coal power plants might be technically or financially viable, 
decarbonization efforts need to consider the significant impact on communities dependent on the 
coal sector (so-called stranded regions), who will lose jobs and revenues. It is important that 
communities are not left behind in the transition to a low-carbon society.8 Such policies should 
include the restructuring plans of the coal sector, economic diversification plans for affected 
regions, fiscal measures for affected communities, incentives for investors, skills training, and 
opportunities for workers, with the ultimate objective of leaving affected communities better-off, 
accounting for different needs and challenges of disadvantaged groups, including women, ethnic 
minorities, and the poor. Building on its safeguard policies and a wealth of technical and financial 
assistance, ADB is well-placed to support this “just transition” in DMCs.9 
 
5.  Proposed solutions. The small-scale knowledge and support technical assistance (S-
KSTA)  will  help  selected governments and  relevant  stakeholders  of  up  to  three  DMCs  in 
Southeast Asia region, particularly the largest coal users,10 to analyze and assess the current and 
future costs of maintaining or expanding their coal power plant generation capacity in order to 
initiate a phase out of coal power generation and substitute it with alternative cleaner energy 
sources, in a fair, inclusive, and balanced manner.  
 
6.  The TA will assess the policy and regulatory environment under which coal power plants 
are operating in each DMC in order to understand the feasibility of acquiring, retiring and replacing 
coal power plants. In addition, this assessment will include a review of each country’s energy 
policy, including incentives and subsidies for different technologies, a high-level view of the overall 
generation mix (operational, in construction, planned) and a forecast for energy demand to frame 
what role coal and renewables will need to play within each country’s energy system. 
 
7.  Based on the results of the high-level screening, detailed financial analysis of 2–3 
representative power plants in each DMC will be undertaken. This individual plant analysis will be 
used to estimate the financial and economic value of a significant share, say 50%, of each 
country’s coal fleet that could be retired early. This will include sensitivity analysis of the key 
factors that will significantly affect the value, and account for indirect and direct subsidies that 
might pertain to the existing coal-fleet in these DMCs. 
 
8.  The TA will also help define the terms of reference for a full feasibility study with a larger 
scope and timeframe, which would design the structure of a pilot Coal Replacement Fund (CRF) 
aimed at replacing coal power generation with clean technologies, taking into consideration the 
restructuring  of  the  sector  in  a  balanced  and  fair  manner,  particularly  for  the  affected

9.  This work is to be procured in Q3 2021. The CRF could be funded by long-term investors 
that can tap on very low funding costs, including public financing from each DMC, bilateral and 
multilateral development organizations, and eventually private investors). In return, each DMC 
will commit to an agreed schedule for decommissioning and replacement their coal power fleet, 
with agreed standards for energy access, security and considerations for “just transition” in the 
affected regions.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  Based on the design and monitoring framework (DMF), the TA is aligned with the following 
impact: encourage DMCs to shift to a low greenhouse gas emission development path in line with 
their nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement.  The TA will have the 
following outcome: pre-feasibility level analysis of a CRF mechanism in selected Southeast Asian 
DMCs completed.

ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan is in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The Energy Division (SEEN) of the Southeast Asia Regional 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The TA will be implemented from 
March 2021 to November 2021. The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time).

15.  Consulting services. The TA will require 8.7 person-months of individual international 
consultant services. The consultants will be recruited through individual consultant selection 
method  and  will  consist  of  specialists  in  energy  policy,  energy  technologies  and  financial 
modelling. Country experience and knowledge of energy sectors in targeted countries is preferred. 
ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from 
time to time) and its associated staff instructions. The terms of reference for the consultants are 
accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2.
